image.altText: A small house with a thatched roof surrounded by trees and a line drapped in clothes.

props.synopsis: When a woman was accused of using witchcraft in PNG to kill a young boy, she was attacked and left for dead. She survived thanks to the help of strangers and a safe house offering refuge for victims of sorcery-related violence.

title.children: The sudden death of Elli's relative led to her being branded a witch. She barely escaped with her life

image.altText: A photo of a woman and a man holding up sheets of paper.

props.synopsis: Animal Justice Party MP Georgie Purcell has been banned from all duck hunting wetlands until the end of the season after illegally entering waters.

title.children: 'I don't regret a thing': Victorian MP banned all from duck hunting wetlands after illegally entering waters

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and glasses walks down a street.

title.children: 'Bloodthirsty' or an ethical way to source meat? A clash of ideas on a wetlands battlefield

title.children: Melbourne confirmed as scene for Lewis Hamilton's Ferrari debut

image.altText: Hannah Clarke, hugs her son Trey Baxter, while standing on a beach.

image.altText: A group of people and rescue workers wearing helmets walk along a grey tunnel.

title.children: For millions of years, the earth here has been rising up. Now two Australians are lost on Mysterious Valley Trail

image.altText: Thousands of used tyres in piles spread out over a brown landscape.

image.altText: A road sign indicating a 60-kph speed limit.

props.synopsis: A motorist accused of travelling well over the speed limit has won his appeal, with the Supreme Court finding there was no proof the speed gun had been operated correctly.

title.children: Driver of car clocked 51kph over limit in Adelaide successfully challenges speed gun finding

image.altText: Graffiti artist Byron Christensen  2024-03-22 11:03:00

title.children: Graffiti was an 'escape' for Byron during a tough childhood. Now his story and skills are inspiring others

image.altText: Two TAFE apprentice chefs cook in the kitchen.

props.synopsis: Restaurant owners may soon have to look locally for chefs if the federal government follows through on its 'skill-first' migration shake-up.

title.children: Chefs could be on the chopping block in migration shake-up

image.altText: a blonde woman holds a sign

title.children: Hundreds in Ballarat call for an end to violence against women, as shadows of three major tragedies loom

image.altText: A view of Jewel casino across Vila Bay at Iririki Resort, with hibiscus flowers in the foreground.

image.altText: Virginia Trioli pulls a weight machine towards her as she sits, smiling, in workout gear

title.children: A scary fall in an emergency was a sobering reminder that ageing happens to all of us â yes, even you

image.altText: A colourful cartoon house with a For Sale sign out the front.

props.synopsis: Australia's favourite family appear to be on the move, but the hilarity and warmth that Bluey provides are in stark contrast to the reality of a housing crisis that's making life difficult for families like the Heelers. And yes, I'm aware they're a fictional family of cartoon dogs.

title.children: Bluey's family might be selling their house. What does it mean that they couldn't afford to buy it?

image.altText: Vivian sitting at home.

props.synopsis: These men have all badly hurt a partner or relative. They've even done time for it, but can they change for good? The ABC has been given exclusive access to a program that is helping them turn their lives around.

title.children: This was the moment a man who'd spent 30 years in and out of prison decided to retire

image.altText: Closed off street by police after Doonside stabbing 120424

props.synopsis: A 16-year-old boy will appear in court today charged with murder after two teenagers were stabbed, one fatally, in Sydney's west yesterday.

title.children: 16yo boy charged with murder after fatal stabbing near school in Sydney's west

image.altText: A crop of a square video, showing a blonde woman wearing a dark blue flak jacket.

props.synopsis: A UNICEF aid worker recounts the moment her aid convoy, which had informed both parties in the Israel-Gaza conflict of its movements, was hit by bullets in Gaza.

title.children: Australian aid worker's convoy hit by bullets while delivering aid in Gaza

image.altText: Two men in blue shirts taking photographs on a beach

props.synopsis: Liberals' candidate for the seat of Cook, Simon Kennedy, won't be able to personally boost voter turnout as his team confirmed he didn't move into the electorate in time to meet the registration deadline.

title.children: Liberal candidate to replace Scott Morrison can't vote for himself in tonight's by-election

image.altText: a photo of a woman standing in front of the entrance to a shed with a netball in her hand and a face mask on

title.children: 'Mouldy sheep shed' used as netball change room closed by council amid health concerns

image.altText: nickelback hate to love

props.synopsis: Nickelback had a chance to own the narrative around why they're so hated with their official documentary. Instead, they double-down on their formulaic approach to keeping their fans entertained.

title.children: Nickelback are 'the most hated band in the world'. Their new documentary won't win them any new fans

image.altText: Man stands in front of a boat, ankle-deep in ocean water, looking pensively out to sea.

props.synopsis: The seafood company comes to the area to run Cone Bay Barramundi with a controversial reputation, but insists it wants to build a healthy relationship with the community.

title.children: Apprehension surrounds seafood giant Tassal's move into remote Kimberley coast

image.altText: The historic buildings of Cossack are closed heading into the tourist season.

props.synopsis: Western Australia's premier Roger Cook has been called to intervene and help reopen the historical Pilbara ghost town of Cossack, after a traditional owner group walked away during a dispute with the government.

title.children: WA Premier Roger Cook calls for ghost town dispute to be resolved

image.altText: A woman sits on the couch and studies.

props.synopsis: Stephanie Grieve decided 2024 was the year she stopped putting her veterinary nurse dreams on hold. But with four children and 16 pets, full-time study via distance education is a balancing act.

title.children: Women more likely to return to study after having children, but for mums it's a juggling act

image.altText: A white sign saying "Hometown not tourist town" on a green field.

props.synopsis: A divisive sign, reading "hometown not tourist town", was erected at Easter then pulled down again by those opposing it, but not before it brought national attention to a community debate.

title.children: Hometown or tourist town? Holiday hotspot makes its feelings known with blunt message for visitors

image.altText: A close up of a plain silver key in a door lock against a background of green foliage.

props.synopsis: The idea of "squatters' rights" has received a lot of media attention recently amid the grim reality of the Australian housing market.Â So where did the doctrine of adverse possession come from, and what has it meant in practice?

title.children: If you squat in a vacant property, does the law give you the house for free? Well, sort of

image.altText: A drawing of a wombat with a runner's number and singlet breaking through a red finish line ribbon

props.synopsis: It's claimed a wombat can run faster than any human over a distance of 100 metres. Now, an exhaustive ABC investigation has tracked down the truth of the 40kph sprinting wombat myth.Â

title.children: How fast can wombats run? We dug into the truth of claims they can beat Usain Bolt
